author: Zach Dennis
title: St. Pete man banned from Starbucks after confronting handicap...
text:
A St. Petersburg man was banned from all Starbucks locations after he was accused of causing a disturbance on multiple occasions when he confronted customers who weren’t handicapped but were parking in the handicapped spot.
According to ABC News , Rob Rowen has been banned from all Starbucks locations after he caused a “disruption” on multiple occasions after he would confront customers who weren’t handicapped, but parked in the disabled parking spot. Rowen said that he would never confront customers in an angry manner and that most of them completely understood while others complained to the manager.
Starbucks "Instead of the manager supporting me ... instead of saying... 'I'm not going to take your order until you move your car,' she [the manager] would take care of them [the customers] and then tell me to leave them alone," he said.
Rowen said that after three months of this happening, the manager finally said he couldn’t visit the coffee shop anymore. "'I don't want you harassing my customers. I don't want you to come back in this store ever,’” he said the manager told him.
After the confrontation with the manager, Rowen said that he “left (the situation) alone,” but received a letter on Thursday that said he was not allowed in any Starbucks location. In the letter, the company said that he was expelled for “causing a disruption to business” and “threatening the well-being of a customer or partner (employee).”
While the issue stems from his interactions with the manager, Rowen said that he is friendly with the baristas and most of them agree with his confrontations with customers who park in handicap spots. 'I'm so sorry, this is on me. Thank you for what you do,’” Rowen said the baristas tell him. He added that he feels compelled to defend this issue since his son-in-law has muscular dystrophy and uses a power wheelchair.
Rowen told ABC News he would not dispute the ban, but a regional executive discussed the issue with Rowen and has agreed to reinstate him.
Read more at ABC News .
